Representative_Docs: ['Diane Rae Gunter Birth: 1939 Death: 2025 Diane Rae Gunter, 86, passed on November 2, 2025 at her home in Soquel surrounded by family. Born May 13, 1939, in Soquel, she graduated from Santa Cruz high school where she met her husband, Jesse Edwin Gunter. She is survived by her daughter, son, grandchildren, and great grandchildren and is pre-deceased by her husband. Diane taught swimming to children for many years at Polly’s Puddle and spent her career working in a sheltered workshop for disabled adults in Oregon. She was an avid tennis and softball player early in life, and she found her love for golf later. She spent much of her time in her garden, often ending the day with a pint of her favorite Guinness. She enjoyed traveling and spending time with family and friends. Diane lived her life on her terms and will be missed by all. A celebration of life will be held January 17, 2026, at DeLaveaga Golf Course from 3 to 6 pm. Honor with Flowers In memory of Diane Rae Plant a Living Memorial In memory of Diane Rae', 'Janet Marie Flores Birth: 1931 Death: 2025 Janet Marie Flores passed away peacefully on November 21, 2025 at the age of 94 surrounded by the love of her family. Jan was born on October 31, 1931 in San Francisco to loving parents Alice Detour and Joseph Hettrick. Jan was a loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother who found her greatest joy in her family. She had a way of making people feel welcomed. She was kind, big hearted, extremely gracious and devoted to those she loved. Her presence will be deeply missed. Jan lived a long life traveling, playing golf, bunco with her friends and one of her greatest talents was to find a treasure at garage sales. In her final years she enjoyed playing penny slots at the casino. The last nine years Jan spent in the loving care of her daughter and son in law. A special thank you to her granddaughter Samantha for making her last days warm, comfortable and full of love. Jan survived by her daughter Tina Schilling (Michael), her grandchildren Michael (Marissa), Paul (Kacie), Samantha (Carlos), and her nine great grandchildren Jackson, Aubrey, Jordan, Mikey, Ellie, Luna, Ryder, Makayla and Stella. And her friends who will forever cherish her memory. Celebration', 'Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser Birth: 1950 Death: 2025 Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser March 16, 1950-December 15, 2025 passed away peacefully surrounded by her family at her home in San Pancho, Mexico. Survived by her husband of 41 years, Phil Schlosser, her mother Gerry, daughter Kelly Noel, son Kevin Noel and wife Jennifer and her grandchildren Trevor and Lena. She was preceded in death by her father, Wayne Henry Jordan and brother Michael Wayne Jordan. Linda was born and raised in San Rafael, CA and graduated from Terra Linda High School. Linda loved sunshine, warm weather and travel. She was an outstanding cook and loved to entertain. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Her family requests that gifts in lieu of flowers be made in Linda’s name to St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: Family, friends don’t seem to appreciate time I put into tedious Christmas cookie tradition Dear Eric: My late mother made a special Christmas cookie that required tedious decorating, considering each person’s personal preference for toppings, and giving them as gifts to family and friends. They always had a place of honor on our family Christmas table. When she was no longer able, she gave me the cookie cutter, and my daughters and I took over the family tradition. It takes the three of us several days to make, bake, decorate, package and mail cookies to family members around the country. We enjoy doing it and feel like we’re continuing the fun and festive tradition. However, in recent years, not all of the recipients acknowledge receipt. At some point in their lives, they have all helped Grandma decorate, so they know the time involved. Because of past delivery issues, I track the boxes and inquire if I haven’t heard from them in a couple of days. Last year, one response was “yes we got them.” This feels unappreciative! In the past most would text a picture of their children with the cookies, which we really enjoyed. We rarely see any of them anymore, as they are busy raising their families and don’t live nearby. This seems like a way for us to continue somewhat of a co', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son’s relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son’s 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? – Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren’t insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It’s not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I’d encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you’re lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family’s hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I’ve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I’ve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it’s radio silence. I guess what I’m asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I’ve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn’t imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won’t talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this façade that I don’t care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he’s been guilty by association yo']

Representative_Docs: ['HNL Lab Medicine Brings Escape Room Fun to Hospital Education ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- HNL Lab Medicine is transforming hospital training by turning mandatory education into an adventure. To strengthen the collaboration between laboratory and nursing teams, HNL Lab Medicine\'s Clinical Hospital Advisors have introduced an innovative "escape room"–style educational game that turns essential lab‐related lessons into an interactive experience. The escape room begins with a familiar challenge: how to avoid getting a phone call from the lab about a rejected sample. The activity takes less than ten minutes per nurse, no longer than a standard training session, but delivers far more excitement and engagement. Representative_Docs: ['AP Sports SummaryBrief at 3:08 p.m. EST MLB pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz charged with taking bribes to rig pitches for bettors NEW YORK (AP) — Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give sports bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they’d throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes to ensure successful bets. Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz both pitched for the Cleveland Guardians. They have been on non-disciplinary paid leave since July while Major League Baseball investigated what it said was unusually high in-game betting activity when they pitched. A lawyer for Ortiz declined to comment when contacted by The Associated Press and a lawyer for Clase did not immediately return messages seeking comment. NFL spokesman Brian McCarthy said Tagliabue’s family informed the league of his death in Chevy Chase, Maryland. Representative_Docs: ["Olympic torch to crisscross Italy on 12,000 kilometer journey The Olympic torch will go on a 12,000 kilometer journey across Italy in the two months leading up to the Winter Olympics in February, Games organizers said on Monday. The relay will take in famous tourist spots including the Colosseum in Rome and the Grand Canal in Venice, as well as stopping in southern cities such as Palermo and Naples to spark excitement in areas where winter sports are not a major feature. The Games will be co-hosted by Milan and the Dolomite resort of Cortina d'Ampezzo and will run from Feb. 6 to 22. “Every step of the relay through our cities will remind the world of the power of sport to build bridges and break down barriers,” said Giovanni Malago, president of the Milano Cortina 2026 Foundation, adding that the journey would celebrate “the essence of Italy.” The torch relay will begin on Nov. 26 when the flame is lit in Olympia, the Greek home of the ancient Games. The flame will be handed over to Italian officials in Athens on Dec. 4 and begin its Italian trip from Rome two days later. Representative_Docs: ['Minnesota high schoolers prepare for once-in-lifetime learning trip to Africa ASHBY, Minn. — There are field trips and there are field trips. Students at Ashby High School are busy raising money and getting ready to pack their bags for a two-week learning experience in South Africa. ADVERTISEMENT When it is below zero, the main street in Ashby, Minnesota, is quiet. Fewer than 500 people call this Grant County town home, but lately the town is busy rallying around a group of high school students. In the basement of Peace Grue Lutheran in the middle of town, five high school students join veteran church quilters in tying quilts that the students will take on their trip to South Africa. "There is a reason the church ladies do this and not the guys," joked Kevin Fick, the girls\' weightlifting coach and organizer of the trip, of tying quilts the students will take with them as gifts. Five girls, along with Fick and four adult chaperones, will make the trip to Eastern Cape, South Africa, from Feb. 28 through March 10. Not as tourists, but to learn about conservation on another continent. "Not a lot of kids get to do this," said student Hadley Hokanson, student.
